talk.start.para: asked the Leader of the Senate, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that the Dutch maintain a highly efficient information service in Melbourne which is the centre for the distribution of considerable propaganda and other information in Australia.?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable senator##'##s questions are as follows : -

item.para: A Netherlands In forma tion Bureau is maintained in Melbourne.

item.label: 2 amd 3.
item.para: Australia is at present represented in the Netherlands East Indiesby a consulgeneral atBatavia with a small staff, which from time to time has been augmented to deal with particular problems. In view of the complex political situation that has existed in the area, no alternative arrangement has been either practicable or appropriate. ##'## Functions of an information nature are being discharged by the consulate-general in the course of its normal duties. These functions are supplemented by daily short-wave broadcasts in Dutch and Malay from Australia. The point to be made is that in South-East Asia, Australia and other powers have had to adapt the nature and scale of their representation to the particular circumstances obtaining from time to time in each country where representation is necessary. In most of these countries there have been varying degrees of instability, of one kind or another, as a result of the Japanese war. This is especially true of the Netherlands East Indies where the prospect of settled conditions is only justnow appearing. The Australian Government, which has already established Australian consular representation at six points in South-East Asia whore none existed before, namely, at Singapore, Manila, Bangkok, Batavia, Dili and Colombo, is fully alive to what is required in the way of future representation. Its proposals in this respect make full provision for an adequate measure of Australian publicity throughout the area.

talk.start.para: .- This clause. I understand, provides that an employee may within a period of twelve months apply to the court for the recovery of wages. That, period is not long enough. I know of a market gardener who employs a man during the day in his gardens, and then. ##]## puts him in has shop on Friday nights, :-##'##nd also, I understand, on Saturdays. In most cases employees who are- called upon to work overtime in this way do not, receive any extra wages.##'## Fearing dismissal if they claim overtime, they usually wait until they are dismissed or decide to leave before taking action to recover the extra money due to them. An employee might continue his employment for three or four years before getting an opportunity to claim overtime. I know of a man who worked overtime . for his employer, but received no payment because he was afraid to ask for it. Labour was not scarce at that time, and he feared losing his job. The aim of this provision is to prevent##'## men knowingly, and in defiance of awards and union principles, continuing year after year to work for less than award rates. talk.start.para: .- It is interesting to note that since the Conciliation andArbitration Act was passed in 1904, the act has been amended no fewer than sixteen times. It has lost a wonderful opportunity to improve its economic position. That is an opportunity which it never had before, and we have not made the best of it.
